From: Michael Neumann <mn.de@...>

Hello Siddhartha,
Tuesday, October 02, 2001, 5:23:05 PM, you wrote:

ST> I am new to junit. I downloaded junit3.7 from junit.org site.
So did I numerous times this year...
ST> Here the textui and swingui packages are not there.
Well - in my downloads the packages (or to be more specific the
classes with that package-prefix) where there. Only the javadoc for
them wasn't prepared.
You can prepare it by decompressing src.jar into a folder of your
choice - lets call it C:\temp\src for now.
A folder "C:\temp\src\junit" will be created, so with your current directory
being TEMP you can create the javadoc with something like
   mkdir api
   dir src\*.java /s /b > junitfiles
   javadoc -d api -public -sourcepath src @junitfiles

unfortunately this doesn't give you the package-frame, that could be
achieved by listing all the junit packages on the commandline
or by using Ant  with a Build.xml like this:
  <project name="junitdoc" basedir="." default="javadoc">
     <target name="javadoc">
       <mkdir dir="api"/>
       <javadoc sourcepath="src"
         destdir="api"
         private="true"
         packagenames="junit.*"/>
     </target>
  </project>

ST> Can anybody tell the simplest method I will set up junit in my
ST> system(Windows 2000)
Just extract the junit.jar from the zip to your favorite directory for
jars...

ST> and how to use it for my JSPs and servlets
Take a look at cactus (http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/)
or HttpUnit (http://sourceforge.net/projects/httpunit)
ST> and java classes.
My personal favorite on how to get a feeling for unit testing is the
testing chapter of "Refactoring" by Martin Fowler...
And of course there are the original articles from Kent Beck and Erich
Gamma (Testinfected) and the cookstour, etc...

hope it helps
-- 
Best regards,
 Michael                            mailto:mn.de@...
subject: Re: [junit] How to use junit
